context.text: One is that you have something, an act, directed, that you have evidence about an act directed to the functioning of the judicial system; and the other, you have some amorphous belief that this person, whether it's because of his background, social status, color perhaps, is more likely to commit a crime.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It is objectively in that category.

context.speaker: Julie S. Levin
context.text: --It isn't a category, but Congress did not intend for states to use neutral statutes or, quote, "neutral" statutes to turn around and do the same prohibited practices that Congress was abolishing.

context.speaker: Julie S. Levin
context.text: In the legislative history it is clear that Congress intended to abolish pregnancy-related disqualifications that disqualify a woman because she left her job on account of pregnancy, or whose unemployment was a result of pregnancy.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But I thought you told Justice O'Connor that it would not violate the statute simply to dismiss somebody for a voluntary quit having nothing to do with the job, if that's all you know.

context.speaker: Julie S. Levin
context.text: If that's all you know, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And step two is that this is a voluntary quit unrelated to the job.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Let me ask one other question, following up on Justice Scalia's.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Supposing you had a form lease that you used that did contravene the statute, so that we have an argument then about whether the tenant could sue for the excess rent.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Would he have a forum in which he could get equitable relief to have a different lease executed to conform to the statute, and if so could he do that in federal court, as he did I guess here?
